title.native: 新世紀GPXサイバーフォーミュラ

description:
14-year-old Kazami Hayato is the youngest driver of Cyber Formula, a Grand Prix in which each vehicle is equipped with computers to aid in racing. With the help of Asurada, the most advanced cybernavigation system, and team Sugo, Hayato races to become the winner of the 10th Cyber Formula Grand Prix. Along the way, Hayato will have to learn what it truly means to be a racer and that victory cannot be achieved simply by driving the best machine. In addition, Kazami will have to gain the respect of the veteran racers, thwart those who attempt to steal Asurada, and participate in races outside of Cyber Formula.

(Source: Anime News Network)

node.description:
[Website](http://www.yatate.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yatate_hajime) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/矢立肇) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajime_Yatate)

Hajime Yatate is a collective pseudonym for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s staff.

Shouji Kawamori is an anime creator, director and mechanical designer. Also a current advisor for [Satelight](https://anilist.co/studio/41/).

Famous for his work in the [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) and Transformers franchises. He pioneered several innovative concepts in his works, such as transforming mecha (including the VF-1 Valkyrie in Macross and Optimus Prime in Transformers) and virtual idols (including Lynn Minmay and Sharon Apple in the Macross franchise).

Kawamori attended Keio University together with Macross screenwriter [Hiroshi Oonogi](https://anilist.co/staff/97701/) and character designer [Haruhiko Mikimoto](https://anilist.co/staff/96968/). There they became friends and founded a [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) fan club called "Gunsight One," a name the group would use years later during the development of the fictional world of the Macross series. Later on his career Kawamori created or co-created the concepts which served as basis for several anime series. His projects are usually noted to contain strong themes of love, war, spirituality or mysticism, and ecological concern.

Kawamori also helped to design various toys for the Takara toyline, Diaclone in the early '80s. Among them the first Optimus Prime toy design, Prowl, Bluestreak, Smokescreen, Ironhide, and Ratchet. Over 20 years later, he returned to Transformers by designing both the Hybrid Style Convoy and the Masterpiece version of Starscream for Takara.

[Profile](https://www.imagine-music.co.jp/artist/index/9) | [Twitter](http://twitter.com/kowotani)

After graduating from university, he became a founding member of Yuji Saito's music production company IMAGINE in November 1986. The company has grown to feature musicians like Kohei Tanaka, Shiro Hamaguchi, Hayato Matsuo, and Shinji Miyazaki, who have become well known for cinematic scoring and orchestration through Otani. 

In 1987, he made his debut as an anime composer with the popular manga adaptation City Hunter, which earned him recognition in the industry. He later went on to work on titles such as Spy Games (1988), The Ultimate Teacher (1988), The Yadamura Waltz (1988), and You're Under Arrest (1994). The anime Future GPX Cyber Formula (1991) and Mobile Suit Gundam Wing (1995) and several films in the Gamera series are some of his most well-known works.  In 2001, he created the score to the film Godzilla, Mothra and King Ghidorah: Giant Monsters All-Out Attack. Other notable scores by Otani include Outlaw Star (1998), Gundam Wing: Endless Waltz (1998), Cross Fire (2000), The SoulTaker (2001), Haibane Renmei (2002), Zatch Bell! (2003), Eyeshield 21 (2005), Pumpkin Scissors (2006), Deltora Quest (2007), and Over Drive (2007). He has also been the music director and keyboardist of the band Dreams Come True. He appeared at Eminence Symphony Orchestra's events A Night in Fantasia 2007: Symphonic Games Edition and Unearthing Eden ~The sounds of AINARU~ in 2007.  

Throughout his career, Otani has also composed music for several video games, making his debut with the 1995 shooter game Philosoma. In 2000, he created the soundtrack to the flight simulator Sky Odyssey. He scored Shadow of the Colossus in 2005, his most famous video game work. Otani was responsible for composing the music for Wild Arms: Twilight Venom (2000), an anime adaptation of the Wild Arms video game series; he also arranged compositions of Michiko Naruke's music from the series. He did two more video game to anime adaptations: Night Warriors: Darkstalkers' Revenge (1997) and Popolocrois Monogatari (1998). In 2005, he created the track "Madness" alongside Hiroko Shigezumi for the Square Enix game Heavy Metal Thunder.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/75655903) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/something_Yoshimatsu/)

Affiliated with Studio Live since 1982. Studied under [Toyoo Ashida](https://anilist.co/staff/110953/). He has deep ties into [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) ever since working as a character designer on [Trigun](https://anilist.co/anime/6/) in 1998. A member of the Japanese Animation Creators Association (JAniCA).

Works as a mangaka under the name Something Yoshimatsu (サムシング吉松).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1002418889362272256) | [Blog](https://ameblo.jp/inomata-mutsumi/)

An animator turned illustrator originally from [Ashi Productions](https://anilist.co/studio/196/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%98%9F%E5%B1%B1%E5%8D%9A%E4%B9%8B)

Hiroyuki Hoshiyama was a renown screenwriter. He started his career in [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1967, but left it later in 1973 and worked as a freelancer until his passing.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%98%9F%E5%B1%B1%E5%8D%9A%E4%B9%8B)

Hiroyuki Hoshiyama was a renown screenwriter. He started his career in [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1967, but left it later in 1973 and worked as a freelancer until his passing.

He's a screenwriter who mainly deals with anime works.  During his training, he also studied under Kohan Kawauchi. In that connection, he also participates in anime and special effects works based on Kawauchi. In the 1980s, he was active in working on multiple works at the same time. There is a wide range of genres, from gag lines to serious ones. In recent years, he has also worked on original works such as graphic novels for men. Since the 2000s, he has been working on period drama novels.

He graduated from Hôsei University.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/池田繁美)

Founder and representative director of Atelier Musa.

Shimada graduated from the Department of Education at Waseda University. In 1981, when she was in her third university year, she learned that Toei Douga was recruiting new employees and took an exam to become a trainee director. The studio's policy at the time was not to employ women as directors, and although she scored top marks in the exam, she was encouraged to try writing screenplays instead. She made her debut with a script for episode 42 of Dr. Slump: Arale-chan, which was aired on 10 February 1982. After that, she established a successful career in scriptwriting. On 15 December 2017, she passed away at age 58 from an undisclosed disease.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/fukuda320)

Rose to prominence by directing Shin Seiki GPX Cyber Formula which won the Animage Anime Grand Prix award. 

Fukuda also directed two more Anime Grand Prix award winners - Gundam SEED and Gundam SEED Destiny. With Gundam SEED, Fukuda managed to revive the popularity of Gundam after the commercial failures of Gundam X and Turn A Gundam, which is mostly observed by the selling power of Gundam model kits and toys that Bandai sells.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/75655903) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/something_Yoshimatsu/)

Affiliated with Studio Live since 1982. Studied under [Toyoo Ashida](https://anilist.co/staff/110953/). He has deep ties into [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) ever since working as a character designer on [Trigun](https://anilist.co/anime/6/) in 1998. A member of the Japanese Animation Creators Association (JAniCA).

Works as a mangaka under the name Something Yoshimatsu (サムシング吉松).
Kazunori Nakazawa is a mechanical designer.

Originating from [Asahi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/406/). He joined [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) when it was founded and became the head of its photography department. Since then he has acted as a photographic director on most of Ghibli's films.

Fujino Sadayoshi is a sound director working for Cruise. He has mostly worked on anime shows produced by Sunrise and Nippon Animation. He was married to actress and voice actress [Fujii Kayoko](https://anilist.co/staff/105105/Kayoko-Fujii).
